the Justia client newsletter!

Get an inside look at new developments in online marketing, keep up with the latest social media trends, and hear what’s happening at Justia.

FEATURED NEWS

5 Tips for Building Your LinkedIn Profile

LinkedIn is the world's most popular professional social network, and the most heavily utilized social network for lawyers. In our latest Onward blog post, Justia's SEO professionals explain how you can implement five simple steps to build your profile and get the most out of LinkedIn. These strategies can help you increase your visibility, connect with prospective clients, and grow your practice.

TIP OF THE MONTH

Make Your Mark: Create a Homepage to Impress Visitors & Search Engines

Your homepage is the most important page on your law firm website. It is typically the strongest page for the most competitive search queries and can have a direct impact on the visibility of your site in Google organic and Google My Business / Google Map search results. At a minimum, we recommend the following for your homepage:

  • At least 1,000 words of high-quality and original information
  • Information about your core practice areas or services, offset by descriptive headings
  • A variety of keyword phrases that include the words lawyer(s), attorney(s), or law firm, as well as your main location and key practice areas.

If you have questions about the best practices for writing homepages, don't hesitate to reach out to us.

Tech News

Judge Rules Canada's De-Indexing Order Won't Apply to Google in the U.S.

In a decision applauded by internet free speech advocates, a U.S. District Court has ruled that a Canadian Supreme Court decision requiring Google to globally de-index hundreds of websites belonging to the losing party in a trade secrets dispute does not apply in the U.S. Amicus briefs submitted on Google’s behalf voiced concerns about the Canadian ruling leading to widespread censorship by foreign governments via restrictive speech laws. Judge Edward Davila ruled that the Canadian order violated the Communications Decency Act in the U.S. by holding Google responsible for content posted by others.

Apple's $119.6 Million Victory in iPhone Utility Patent Battle with Samsung Finally Upheld

The U.S. Supreme Court has rejected Samsung’s most recent attempt to throw out a 2014 verdict awarding Apple close to $120 million in a patent infringement dispute. A jury found that Samsung had infringed on patents including Apple’s slide-to-unlock screen technology, and the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit ultimately upheld the damages award. Samsung sought review, alleging failure by the appellate court to consider evidence and oral arguments, among other things. The Supreme Court declined to hear the case, leaving the lower court’s ruling in place.

Google to Introduce 8 Trust Indicators for Publishers to Add to News Stories

In its ongoing initiative to connect users with trustworthy news content, Google has announced plans to add eight new trust indicators to news search results. Working in conjunction with the Trust Project and over 75 news organizations, Google will utilize these factors to highlight content attributes such as author expertise, citations, and methods. The eight new indicators will join Google’s Fact Check tag and Knowledge Panels as quality control measures that the search giant has rolled out within the past year to give users additional context for news search results.

FCC Approves New Rules to Block Robocalls

As part of its effort to curb the ever-growing problem of robocalls, the FCC has approved new rules allowing telecom carriers to block calls that seem fraudulent. Experts predict that the new rules will only prevent an estimated 10% of robocalls, and that scammers will soon change their methods to get around these new barriers. However, telecom industry leaders support the move as a first step toward clarifying what carriers are allowed to do to block these calls.

FCC Releases Final Proposal to End Net Neutrality

The FCC has disseminated the final draft of its plan to dismantle most net neutrality rules. Trump-appointed FCC Chair Ajit Pai has long signaled his intention to remove these regulations, which passed under President Obama and banned blocking, throttling, and paid prioritization of consumer internet content. Though ISPs must publicly disclose these actions under the proposed rules, net neutrality proponents are concerned that they lack adequate consumer protections. The proposal will go to a vote in December and is expected to pass.

SEO News

Google: Improving Low Quality Content is Better Than Deleting It

Google recently clarified that improving low quality content on your site is usually better than deleting it altogether. In some situations, such as when you simply have too much poor quality content, removing the content is best. However, in general, Google’s recommended approach is to clean up the content you have and make sure it is useful.

Google Will Require AMP and Canonical Pages to Match as of February 1, 2018

Next year, Google will start enforcing its requirement that accelerated mobile pages (AMP) and canonical pages maintain content parity. AMP pages that contain only snippets of the canonical page content, for example, will no longer be eligible for inclusion in AMP search results. Instead, users will be sent to the non-AMP version of that page, which may have slower load times. Though there is no penalty per se, this potential loss in visibility provides webmasters with an incentive to comply with the content parity requirement.

Google Rolls Out AdWords Promotion Extensions, Custom Intent Audiences & Ad Variations for Testing

Google will be offering some new features to its advertisers on its AdWords platform. Google is rolling out promotional extensions in text ads worldwide in every supported AdWords language and currency within the new AdWords interface. In addition, auto-generated custom intent audience lists will be viewable in the Audience Center. Each will display reach and performance estimates. The new AdWords interface will also help advertisers test ad variations which employ different headlines, display paths, and descriptions.

Firefox Ditches Yahoo for Google as Default Search Provider

In conjunction with Mozilla’s Firefox Quantum release, the company announced that Google will return as the default search provider on Firefox. Mozilla had previously partnered with Yahoo; however, the company cited the speed of Google’s search engine as well as the prevalence of accelerated mobile pages (AMP) within it for its decision to make the change. Firefox Quantum is available now for desktop operating systems. Users have the option to manually change their default search engine back to Yahoo or another search engine if they prefer.

Reviews Are the Most Prominent Local SEO Ranking Factor in 2017

According to Local SEO Guide’s annual study of local SEO ranking factors, reviews are one of the most important local search ranking factors. Over 200 factors across more than 100,000 local businesses were examined in the study to identify similarities between the well-ranking businesses in Google’s local pack. While it was determined that a business with a significant number of reviews can rank well in local packs, it appears that the content of what is said in these reviews is even more important. Reviews that reference a keyword (geographical or otherwise), for example, were discovered to have stronger rankings. This finding is just one of a handful of important takeaways that business owners can reference when fine-tuning their SEO strategy.

Google Rolls Out a Fresh Look for Mobile Search Results

Google’s latest update to its mobile search results introduces a new look that more closely resembles the devices on which users are viewing them. Rounded corners have replaced a formerly sharp-cornered look, for instance, and they now align with the edge-to-edge displays on the latest smartphones. The blue link color has also been lightened, and review stars on local business listings are now yellow instead of their previous orange. This newest update appears to be exclusively aesthetic, with the rendering of search results remaining unchanged.

MEET OUR TEAM

Justia on Ice

When people think about sports in California, ice skating probably isn’t on the top of their lists, even though our state has a reputation for producing champion figure skaters. Andrew, a member of our Writing Services team, has been an avid skater for years and continues to enjoy skating as an adult. He recently passed his US Figure Skating Senior Free Skate test and qualified for the 2017 National Showcase Championships that were held in Santa Rosa, where his team took home a silver medal in the production ensemble event.

Justia Lead Engineer Dan Vu Quoc Meets Tim Cook

Silicon Valley was abuzz recently with the release of the new iPhone X. Dan, one of our Mountain View-based engineers, was lucky enough to meet Apple CEO Tim Cook when he picked up his new phone in Palo Alto. You just never know who you’ll bump into at the Apple Store!

Social Media News

Twitter Bumps Display Name Length Up to 50 Characters

Beginning on November 9, Twitter user display names can be up to 50 characters in length. This is an increase from the original 20 and will allow users with longer names to fully display them on their profiles. It also offers users more creativity to include emoji without exceeding the display name character limit. While many users seemed to welcome the change, others questioned why Twitter seemed to be focusing on a seemingly inconsequential feature instead of tackling recurrent problems associated with harassment on its platform.

Twitter Doubles Character Limit to 280, Says Longer Tweets Drive More Engagement

Twitter has increased its character limit from 140 to 280, effectively doubling the length of tweets users can publish on the social network. The change went into effect on November 7, and is intended to drive more engagement among users. This increase applies to all languages except Japanese, Korean, and Chinese, which remain limited to a 140-character maximum per tweet.

12 Ways LinkedIn Can Grow Your Brand’s Content Marketing Strategy

Law firms should include LinkedIn when formulating their content management strategy. This social media platform for professionals provides lawyers with some unique opportunities to establish their influence by sharing branded content. Lawyers who successfully build relationships with other attorneys and businesses, as well as stand out as thought leaders, can expand their network and reach more potential clients.

Twitter Confirms It’s Testing a New ‘Tweetstorm’ Feature For Lengthy Rants

Twitter is testing a new feature for those messages that cannot fit in a 140- or 280-character tweet. This “tweetstorm” option allows users to compose a series of tweets all at once without having to number them manually. Twitter confirmed that they were testing this option in its Android and iOS apps.

Legal Industry News

OK, We Get Technology Competence, But How Do We Get Technologically Competent?

An increasing number of states are imposing the duty of technology competence on lawyers. In this survey, Robert Ambrogi looks at the different approaches that law firms can follow to reach that standard, including Florida’s CLE requirement dedicated to technology training, Suffolk University Law School’s Certificate in Legal Technology program, and The Center for Legal Services Innovation’s Law School Innovation Index, which measures law student preparedness for delivering legal services in the 21st century.

IP, Legal Ethics, And The Cloud: 3 Things To Consider Regarding Client Confidential Information

Maintaining the confidentiality of client communications is one of the core responsibilities of legal professionals. If that confidentiality is violated, the breach in trust may not only impact the attorney-client relationship but also present serious consequences for the client’s legal claims. Accordingly, attorneys must tread carefully when adopting software-as-a-service (SaaS) solutions in their legal practice. Read about the precautions that should be taken before moving your documents and data to the cloud.

Bitcoin and the Legal Ethics of Lawyers

Professor Ronald D. Rotunda comments on a recent Nebraska bar ethics advisory opinion that requires lawyers who accept bitcoin or other digital currencies as payment to immediately convert them to dollars. Rotunda argues that devising a special rule for digital currencies is not warranted since it is no different from other forms of payment, including securities and foreign currencies.

Why Are Women Lawyers Leaving the Profession Mid-Career? ABA Initiative Takes Up Issue

Last month, Harvard Law School hosted the ABA National Summit on Achieving Long-Term Careers for Women in Law to study why experienced women lawyers were leaving the legal profession mid-career. This initiative seeks to collect empirical data on the reasons for the exodus and will present results next summer.
